title: 108_hr4416
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee Act". The Act establishes the Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee. The "Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee" is established to conduct a study on programs for restoring the Great Lakes, make recommendations for prioritization, legislation, and funding, and improve coordination among programs and governments. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee will analyze Federal and State funding for programs aimed at restoring the Great Lakes over a 10-year period. They will assess the success of these programs and project their expected accomplishments based on existing funding levels. The Committee is required to submit a report to the President, Congress, and Governors of Great Lakes States within one year of their initial meeting. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee will provide a report to the national Government of Canada, the Governors of the Great Lakes States, and the Premiers of Ontario and Quebec. The report will include study results, restoration goal prioritization recommendations, 10-year benchmarks for goal achievement, and proposed legislation for additional funding and authority. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee will provide recommendations for improving coordination among existing federal, state, local, and non-governmental programs, as well as between the US and Canadian governments, regarding environmental protection and restoration activities in the Great Lakes. The Committee will consist of 25 voting members, including the Governors of the Great Lakes States. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee will consist of 25 voting members, including 8 Governors of the Great Lakes States and 13 members appointed by the President representing various federal agencies. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee will consist of 25 voting members, including 8 Governors of the Great Lakes States and 13 members appointed by the President representing various federal agencies. Additionally, there will be 10 nonvoting members appointed by the President. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee will have 10 voting members, including representatives from the environmental community, industry, scientific community, Indian tribes, Great Lakes Fishery Commission, and International Joint Commission. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee, established by the Boundary Waters Treaty of 1909, will have 10 voting members and may include nonvoting observers such as the Premiers of Ontario and Quebec, a representative of the Canadian government, and a representative of the Department of State. Members will be appointed within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, serve for the life of the Committee, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee, established by the Boundary Waters Treaty of 1909, will have 10 voting members and may include nonvoting observers. Members will be appointed within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, serve for the life of the Committee, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee shall select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members, who shall serve without pay and be allowed travel expenses. Meetings will be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Committee, established by the Boundary Waters Treaty of 1909, will meet at the call of the Chairperson. A majority of voting members shall constitute a quorum, and the Committee may hold hearings, receive evidence, and secure information from federal agencies as needed. The Committee established by the Boundary Waters Treaty of 1909 may use postal services and accept gifts. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and other necessary staff, with the authority to fix compensation. The Committee established by the Boundary Waters Treaty of 1909 can appoint an executive director and staff, with the Chairperson having the authority to set their compensation without following certain federal regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Committee can appoint an executive director and staff, with the Chairperson setting their compensation. Federal employees can be detailed without reimbursement or loss of civil service status. The Committee may procure temporary services as needed. The Committee will terminate 90 days after submitting a report. Definitions include "Great Lakes" referring to Lake Erie. The term "Great Lakes" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, Lake Superior, and connecting channels. "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin. "Great Lakes region" encompasses these states. "Indian tribe" is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations totaling $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2005 is provided for this section, with funds remaining available until the Committee's termination.
